title: remove minimum 32-bit restriction
body:
Change minimum 32-bit restriction for floating point types to 8-bit.
This change is to enable reduced precision types that may use vector operations underneath the hood (cases where #lanes > 1 such as half4).

title: [ROCM] remove fma dispatch
body:
Turned out fma instruction was causing severe performance regression for gemm and resnet inference.
For gemm, it dropped to 1800 GFLOPs from 5200 GFLOPs. 

Removing fma instruction dispatch allows LLVM AMDGPU backend to generate mac instruction instead, which solved the performance regression problem.

Enables viewing generated LLVM IR or GCN assembly with:

```
dev_module = func.imported_modules[0]
print(dev_module.get_source("llvm"))
print(dev_module.get_source("asm"))
```

title: [TOPI] add conv2d_transpose_nchw
body:
1. conv2d_transpose is almost the same as conv2d, except that conv2d_transpose has a dilation stage, and the filter is rotated by 180 degrees. It's reusing conv2d's cuda schedule.

2. According to the nnvm doc [http://nnvm.tvmlang.org/top.html#nnvm.symbol.conv2d_transpose](http://nnvm.tvmlang.org/top.html#nnvm.symbol.conv2d_transpose), there seems a padding stage after the convolution. This is not supported for now, becasue I am not clear about the purpose of this padding operation and tensorflow doesn't have it in tf.nn.conv2d_transpose(). Also, bias and groups are not supported for now.

repo.name: tvm
repo.description: Open deep learning compiler stack for cpu, gpu and specialized accelerators

title: [PASS] More robust UnrollLoop configuratin
body:
Previously the auto un-roller will simply detect how many steps of the loop, and unroll the loop with steps smaller than this value. This creates troublesome unrolling cases like deep nested for loops with each containing a small extent value.

This PR changes the behavior of auto loop unroller to solve this problem.

- Instead of count how many steps in the loop, we multiply the step by the number of statements in the loop body. In the following code, if ```auto_max_step = 8```, only two level(ry, k) will be unrolled).
- We also control how many nested level that can be unrolled automatically, this is given by ```auto_max_depth```, if we set auto_max_depth=1, then only k will be unrolled.
- The original auto_min_depth parameter is removed.

```
for rx in [0, 3]:
   for ry in [0, 4]:
       for k in [0, 2]:
           one stmt.
```

This change is not compatible with the old configuration of unroller. So we need to confirm the regression performance of existing code, and update accordingly.
- ```auto_max_depth``` usually can be left as default
- ```auto_max_step``` in GPU is recommended to set to a reasonable value, say 128.  If we find there are left over loops that we want to unroll, we can use unroll primitives explicitly.

title: [ROCM] Working math function support for ROCm backend, a bug fix in LLVM based codegen
body:
This PR adds working math function support to ROCm backend. It supersedes #553.
It also fixes a bug in external function call generator in LLVM based codegen. 

With this PR, we can pass test_topi_softmax.py and test_topi_reduce.py.
It also enables running resnet and mobilenet benchmark in nnvm.

Resnet18 and mobilenet benchmark, on R9 Nano
```
$ python cuda_imagenet_bench.py --model resnet
benchmark args: Namespace(model='resnet', num_iter=1000, opt_level=1)
ProfileResult(mean=0.010514197691)
ProfileResult(mean=0.010503243036)
ProfileResult(mean=0.01050078192)
```
```
$ python cuda_imagenet_bench.py --model mobilenet
benchmark args: Namespace(model='mobilenet', num_iter=1000, opt_level=1)
ProfileResult(mean=0.005886083819)
ProfileResult(mean=0.005881836798)
ProfileResult(mean=0.005873367036000001)
```

repo.name: tvm
repo.description: Open deep learning compiler stack for cpu, gpu and specialized accelerators

title: [Refactor] Introduce target generic dispatch system
body:
This is a major refactor to TVM's python build and TOPI's build system. The major goal is to provide a target invariant way of calling TOPI API and enable easy patch in of new schedules under specific target.

In the future, we should always encourage user and NNVM to use the topi.generic functions and specify dispatch using the tvm.target

## Target Generic Function
All schedules under ```topi.generic``` are target generic functions. When a target generic function is called, it will lookup the specific registered implementations under its own registry, call the specific implementation when matched. 

## Target Special Implementation
The target special schedule function can call ```generic_func.register``` to register a target special implementation of the function. 

## Target Keys
Each target has an ordered list of keys, for example, ```[ "cuda", "gpu"]```. When a function is called under a target context, it will match the registered function by the key. So if an implementation is registered under key "cuda", it will be called, if not the function under "gpu" will be called.


## Example
```python
# Default schedule injective
@tvm.target.generic_func
def schedule_injective(outs):
    return tvm.create_schedule([x.op for x in outs])

# Register special schedule function for cuda
@schedule_injective.register(["cuda", "gpu"])
def schedule_injective_cuda(outs):
    ...

with tvm.target.cuda(): 
   # calls  schedule_injective_cuda
    s = schedule_injective(outs)

with tvm.target.rocm(): 
   # calls  schedule_injective_cuda, because it matches the "gpu key"
    s = schedule_injective(outs)

with tvm.target.rasp(): 
   # calls the default schedule_injective
    s = schedule_injective(outs)
```

title: enable rocm target for topi/recipes. add timing util to gemm test.
body:
This commit adds three more tests for rocm backend. All three tests pass.

The import path of get_const_tuple was updated from topi.nn.util to topi.util, following recent change.
  
On R9 Nano, the added timing utility for the gemm recipe shows the following output. Note the difference in performance between OpenCL and Rocm backend.

$ python cuda_gemm_square.py 
Device cuda
Skip because cuda is not enabled
**Device opencl**
[18:43:46] src/runtime/opencl/opencl_device_api.cc:195: Initialize OpenCL platform 'AMD Accelerated Parallel Processing'
[18:43:46] src/runtime/opencl/opencl_device_api.cc:215: opencl(0)='gfx803' cl_device_id=0x7f2277ed4670
average time cost of 10 runs = 3.6301 ms, **4732.62** GFLOPS.
**Device rocm**
average time cost of 10 runs = 3.305 ms, **5198.14** GFLOPS.

repo.name: tvm
repo.description: Open deep learning compiler stack for cpu, gpu and specialized accelerators

title: Add same_as to NodeBase
body:
1. Most class inherited from NodeBase(Schedule, Stage, etc) still have
the convenience of using '==' for object identity. And this is the right
behavior for non-Expr classes.
2. subclasses of ExprOp now create EQ expression when '==' is used.

`__nonzero__` and `__bool__` in EQ and NE is a comprise that in some cases
object identity semantics is still useful, like in unit test. For instance:
````
assert a == b
````

"a == b" will create EQ expression, assert then calls `__nonzero__` of the
result expression. `Expr.__nonzero__` throws exception since it prohibits
evaluating IR expression.

More complex case like:
````
assert a in b # b is dict
````

it will call `__eq__` on a and all keys of b, then `__bool__` on the result
expression. This could not easily be done by same_as.
